The reason why 0! Equals 1 is because when you do 0!= 1!/1! (One factorial over one factorial) it just cancels out to 1. It’s the same if you were to do 2!=3!/3!. When you expand the equation, You would cancel out the 3 on the bottom with the three on the top and be left with 2 times 1 which, of course, is 2!
Thank you for this explanation. This has been very helpful in understanding the basic differences between the two.

Your explanations and way of speaking is so clear.  It really helped me.  And you are just so funny!  "0 factorial equals 1... if you are wondering why... that's just the way it is.  I don't have an answer for you."  This is something that I need to tell my students...LOL!  But on a more serious note I just found out why zero factorial is equal to 1.  Apparently in terms of factorials, zero factorial means an empty set and an empty set can only be ordered one way, so zero factorial is equal to one.

Just wanted to give a heads up to others!! 
Wouldn't the problem at 14:06 (Alabama Permutation) be equal to 840, not 210? It is supposed to be n!/(n-R)!. However, it seems just the number 4 was used instead of subtracting it from 7 to get the correct answer for "(n-R)!". When I enter (7)P(4) into my calculator, it also agrees with 840 as the answer.
Just a heads up -- at 6:06 "divided by r!" should be "multiply by r!". The text is correct but the verbal description is wrong and repeated incorrectly a few times.  Later in the video it's correct.

For anyone looking for an (in my opinion) an easier way to calculate the r-Permutations:
    P(n,r)
For example:
    P(4,3)= 4x3x2

for those of you wondering why 0! = 1:
let's begin with 5! = 5x4x3x2x1
or 5! = 5 x 4! 
->we can conclude that n! = n x (n-1)!

0 factorial is used mainly in permutation and combination. In that field of maths, it denotes the number of ways in which 0 things can be arranged in 0 places, which equals one (the only way is not arranging anything, that's the one way). So, 0 factorial is equal to 1.

0!=1

11:02 you can actually prove that 0! equals 1 coz technically n!=(n+1)!/n+1
That’s coz when you solve it the (n+1)s are gonna cancel out and you’ll just be left with n!

Now so 0!=(0+1)!/(0+1)=1!/1=1/1=1

and (n-1)!= (n-1)*(n-2)*....*3*2*1
